nl.naturalis.nda.elasticsearch.load

Class ElasticSearchLoader<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.naturalis.nda.elasticsearch.load.ElasticSearchLoader<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of object to be converted to and stored as a JSON document
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Closeable, AutoCloseable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BrahmsMultiMediaLoader, BrahmsSpecimenLoader, CoLTaxonLoader, CrsMultiMediaLoader, CrsSpecimenLoader, NsrMultiMediaLoader, NsrTaxonLoader

    public abstract class ElasticSearchLoader<T>
extends Object
implements Closeable

    Abstract base class for objects responsible for the insertion of data into ElasticSearch (a.k.a. indexing). Subclasses must implement only one method: getIdGenerator(), which must extract the ElasticSearch _id from the object to be stored. The assumption is that you will never want to rely on ElasticSearch to generate an ID for you. If you do want this, your implementation can and should simply return null. Subclasses may also override getParentIdGenerator() in case they need to establish parent-child relationships, but this is not required (the Loader class itself already provides a default implementation that just returns null).

    Once you have processed all data from all datasources that you want to index using a particular writer, you should always call flush() on that instance to write any remaining objects in the writer's internal buffer to ElasticSearch. You are practically guranteed to loose data if you don't call flush() when done, because the last object you added (see add) is unlikely to trigger an automatic flush.

    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

    • Constructor Detail

      • ElasticSearchLoader

        public ElasticSearchLoader(IndexManagerNative indexManager,
                           String documentType,
                           int treshold,
                           ETLStatistics stats)
        Create a loader that uses the specified index manager for bulk-indexing documents of the specified document type. Indexing is triggered every time the number of objects added to the loader via the load(List) operations exceeds the specified treshold.
        Parameters:
        indexManager -
        documentType -
        treshold -

    • Method Detail

      • load

        public final void load(List<T> objects)
        Adds the specified objects to a queue of to-be-indexed objects. When the size of the queue reaches the treshold, all objects in the queue are flushed at once to ElasticSearch. In other words, calling load does not necessarily immediately trigger the specified objects to be indexed. The specified list of object is most likely retrieved from a call to Transformer.transform(Object), which is allowed to return an empty list or null if no output can or should be produced from the input object. Therefore, this method explicitly accepts empty lists and null arguments (resulting in a no-op).
        Parameters:
        objects -

      • findInQueue

        public T findInQueue(String id)
        Checks if the specified id belongs to an object that is about to be indexed and, if so, returns the object. This functionality is needed for import programs that enrich existing documents rather than creating new ones. This applies to all CoL import programs except the taxon importer. The synonym importer, literature reference importer and vernacular name importer all enrich taxon documents rather than creating their own type of documents.
        Parameters:
        id -
        Returns:

      • close

        public void close()
           throws IOException
        Just calls flush() so that a try-with-resources instantiation of this writer is guaranteed to flush the object buffer for you.
        Specified by:
        close in interface Closeable
        Specified by:
        close in interface AutoCloseable
        Throws:
        IOException

      • flush

        public void flush()
        Flushes the contents of the internal object buffer to ElasticSearch. While in the midst of processing your data you don't have to call this method explicitly as it is done implicitly by the load method once the size of the buffers exceeds the treshold specified in the constructor. However, you must call this method yourself once all records have been processed to make sure any remaining objects in the buffer are written to ElasticSearch. (Alternatively, you can set up a try-with-resource block to achieve the same.)
